newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU TELLS BELGIUM TO SCRAP VTM'S AD MONOPOLY.
newsitem.headline: EU TELLS BELGIUM TO SCRAP VTM'S AD MONOPOLY.

text.p: The European Commission told Belgium on Thursday to scrap the advertising monopoly granted to Flemish commercial TV channel VTM.

"At the initiative of Competition Commissioner Karel Van Miert, the Commission has adopted a decision finding the exclusive advertising licence given to VTM illegal," the Commission said in a statement.
The Commission rejected an argument by the Flanders government that the monopoly on advertising was intended to safeguard the pluralism of the press.
The government has long resisted abolishing VTM's exclusive rights on the grounds its advertising revenue is distributed among the region's written press, which partly owns VTM.
Speaking on Belgian radio, Van Miert noted however that VTM was currently controlled by three media groups against an initial nine and this weakened the press pluralism argument.
VTM is 44 percent owned by Dutch publishing group VNU. Other shareholders include Belgium's Persgroep NV and Roularta Mediagroep.
Van Miert also said the monopoly could not be justified on 'general good' reasons, such as cultural policy.
VTM's 18-year TV advertising monopoly for Dutch-speaking Flanders, northern Belgium, granted in 1989, has been attacked by rival VT4.
VT4, owned by Nasdaq-listed TV group Scandinavian Broadcasting System , has been broadcasting from London to Flanders to circumvent the monopoly.
VTM threatened on Wednesday to claim 15 to 20 billion francs ($421 to $562 million) in damages from the Flemish government if it lost its advertising monopoly.
Both the Flemish government and the Commission on Thursday poured scorn on the idea.

Regional Economic Affairs and Media Minister Eric Van Rompuy told BRTN radio, "If the European Commission declares us in default today, we'll have to lift the monopoly...and adjust our laws. So I don't really see how there could be a claim for damages."
Van Miert said, "I don't see how on a solid basis one could ask compensation." He suggested that VTM be satisfied that it had enjoyed a monopoly for such a long time.
The Belgian authorities have two months to comply with the decision or face legal action.

The Commission's decision could spark a reshuffle in the ownership of VTM. Luxembourg media group CLT-UFA, which is 50/50 owned by Germany's Bertelsmann AG and Luxembourg holding company Audiofina, has said it is interested in the company's operations.
